items.title: System Design and it’s Importance
items.author: Ayush Kumar
items.description:
Inside a System Design role.

Tech interviewers often ask you to explain what goes on behind the scenes when you navigate to google? Sometimes they ask you to design a system like Twitter or Facebook from scratch.

Mentioned above are some of the ideas I had about system design ever since I joined College but never thought of exploring the field as I didn’t find any useful resource to teach me practical application of this domain. But recently, I completed an amazing Micro-Experience course by Crio.do , where I got to learn the exact thing I needed to get started. Here I’ll be sharing my learning and experience on System Design through this course.

What is System Design ?

Different services have different requirement, different model and different users base. A bank’s system is completely different from social media, little inconsistency in post is not an issue but inconsistency in banking transactions can lead to major disasters. System designing helps to build services to minimise the risk of failure and to ensure smooth experience to end users.

In technical terms, System design is the process of understanding the user’s need and designing the elements of a system such as the architecture, modules and components, the different interfaces of those components and the data that goes through that system. It is meant to satisfy specific needs and requirements of a business or organisation through the engineering of a coherent and well-running system.

Systems design implies a systematic approach to the design of a system. It may take a bottom-up or top-down approach, but either way the process is systematic wherein it takes into account all related variables of the system that needs to be created — from the architecture, to the required hardware and software, right down to the data and how it travels and transforms throughout its travel through the system. Systems design then overlaps with systems analysis, systems engineering and systems architecture.

What is the role of a system designer ?

This popular quote from Silicon Valley explains the role of Gilfoyle as System designer and architect :

“It’s not magic, it’s talent and sweat. People like me ensure your packets get delivered unsniffed. So what do I do? I make sure that one bad config on one key component doesn’t bankrupt the entire company. That’s what I do.”

Of course, Gilfoyle’s role is integral to the company, and he does ensure that systems work well and are secure.

The key output of the System Designer is the Design Specification. The Design Specification should contain detailed instructions and mock-up screen prints so that the programmers know exactly what they have to code for and what the end result should look like.

These are the roles that a system designer performs:

  • The system designer’s role is to develop a comprehensive plan and instructions which can be given to the programmers.
  • Selecting the right technologies to use in terms of software and hardware.
  • Producing the test plan for the testers.
  • Talk to the developers, technicians and engineers before the development stage begins to help them understand what will be needed before the formal design specification is released.
  • Explain to the client, in non-technical terms, how the system will work and to get their feedback and opinions.

What do you need to learn ?

System design is a vast topic but as a beginner you should first get familiarise with following topics:

  • Networks & Protocols
  • Storage, Latency & Throughput
  • Caching
  • Proxies
  • Load Balancing
  • Databases
  • CDN
  • Cloud Services
  • Scalability
  • Consistent hashing
  • Message queue

My Experience with Crio.do

I learned practical application of system design by completing Crio.do System design Micro-Experience course and had an amazing experience on building a real product through their hands-on sessions which I believe is far more superior than traditional classroom learning.

I learned about setting up a DNS to access a VM using a custom domain, adding a load balancer and a CDN to handle large traffic volume with ease, all via crio’s learn-by-doing methodology.

I really loved the platform and their way of teaching that focused on learning through the hard way. Their curriculum is quite challenging and goes through extreme work like environment which accurately goes with “there is no shortcut to success” .

If you prefer practical knowledge over theoretical, I highly recommend you to try their free course on system design ( https://crio.do/detail/ME_QPREP_SD ) .

You can also refer these resources for in depth knowledge :

  • System Design micro-experience
  • System design playlist by Gaurav Sen
  • System Design Interview Questions by FreeCodeCamp

Conclusion

The experience I had was overwhelming. Be it my first, I got exposed to the concepts above and believe it or not, this surely is gonna help me in future when I’ll actually be joining the industry.
